ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to get through large reading assignments with a view to discussing them.

I learned about how the exact same historical event/period can be interpreted completely differently, depending on the approach of the historian. Often, classes are moving so fast that you only read one person's opinion on a topic, but in this course you are given the chance to explore a number of approaches to witchcraft in colonial New England.
This was a great class for getting better at interpreting primary source documents.

- How gender, puritanism, small communities, the family structure, and other social factors of colonial New England influenced witchcraft accusations
- Read and analyze primary sources on witchcraft like ministers' sermons and court testimonies
- Think critically about the practice of history and how we create a narrative with limited information
Witchcraft in colonial America (obviously) and what factors led to witchcraft cases/accusations; working with limited historical archives; comparing historical perspectives and arguments
I learned about witchcraft, its origins and its aftermath, in Puritan New England.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The atmosphere of the course is very good and Professor Tannenbaum is a very nice person who runs the discussion well. I think the course material gets repetitive after about a month. Maybe having some weeks looking at Witchcraft trials in Europe might be interesting.

The major weakness of this class is that there is simply not enough on the subject of witchcraft in colonial New England to justify a semester of investigation. This resulted in reading very similar arguments across multiple sources and seminar discussions that quickly petered out, as we ran out of things to talk about.
The content is just fabulous in this course. I found the structure really satisfying and logical. Discussion was always wonderful.

Strengths: Discussion was facilitated in an incredible way by the professor and the questions we looked into were fascinating. Professor Tannenbaum also gave great feedback on essays. 
Weaknesses: The readings were often too long.
A bit repetitive in terms of source material/content at times

Strengths: Prof T, who is very understanding and resourceful; interesting readings; clear essay prompts and opportunities to write about history in different ways 
Weaknesses: Material could get a bit repetitive at times
Weakness: reading an entire book a week was way too much of a load to keep up with. It would be more meaningful to engage with smaller amounts of material with more depth.

Strengths: class discussion was always fascinating, some readings were intriguing
Weaknesses: became repetitive

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would only recommend to History majors as it fulfils a lot of requirements. Also, to someone who is VERY interested in witchcraft trials in New England because the material can become monotonous. It is graded harsher than any other course I have taken so be prepared for that!

I would not recommend this course to another student. The reading load is quite heavy (one book each week) and you don't get enough out of the class to make this workload worth it. It is quite hard to remain engaged in class itself, as discussions lacked enthusiasm.

Absolutely. You're gonna learn about witchcraft in colonial New England. It's super cool. An exceptionally fun and interesting class. There aren't a lot of classes at Yale that deal with subject matter like this.
Yes! Witchcraft is and endlessly fascinating topic and Professor Tannenbaum teaches it very well.
if you're into witchcraft, absolutely!
yes! the grading is tough though
